two years now and so I've got a kind of general focus within AWS where I work
with a lot of customers in the new economy in start-up areas but I also have a kind of key interest in the AI
and machine learning space and so in terms of what we're going to cover today it's going to be first of all looking at
how we can use sage maker for fraud detection so I want to give you a little bit of the history of fraud detection
from my perspective and this will be kind of geared towards a payment card industry but really with fraud detection
you could extrapolate that to be a number of different areas anywhere where there could be kind of undesirable
behavior that you want to identify in classify you could use this for and I
mentioned a little bit about machine learning within Amazon itself and then talk a bit about the kind of underlying
architecture of sage maker and then finally give you a bit of a live demo so
in terms of payment fraud it's a kind of ongoing concern for a large number of
financial services organizations and there was a Nielsen report that was published last October where it said
that in 2016 there was almost 23 billion dollars of fraud losses globally and
based on their data they projected that's going to be almost thirty three billion dollars of a loss in our 2021 so
it really is a huge area that has got a lot of focus on and there may be some
people in the room today that actually implement their own fraud detection systems and they might be on a
rule-based version or they might be something that might be using some machine learning services so hopefully
that will give you a bit of an insight into what's possible today and to do it in a fairly sort of quick way as well so
in terms of fraudulent behavior there's effectively I'm looking at it from five different layers so at the very top
layer you've got the kind of endpoint authentication fraudulent area and this
is really where you might have say a skimmer on a cache point you might have a compromised payment terminal
it could be something at the point purchase and the second
part is really looking at the behavior of customers so we're talking about anomaly in a session here and that can
be in a normal behavior where a customer logs into a their account they might do
something like they might check a balance they might make a transfer and then they log off in it kind of
fraudulent whirls that might be run by a bot and so the actions may be a little
bit different so they might log in go immediately to creating a transaction and then disappear and so this is the
second kind of layer where we're trying to identify different pieces of fraud the third layer is again a kind of
deeper more complex layer and this is where for example in this case a fraudster could actually create a direct
debit within your account and normally everyone in this room has probably got direct debit setup they would typically
come out once a month with the fraudster you might have hundreds of transactions in a month so that would be some kind of
anomalous behavior there then you can kind of go even deeper and so this is
why you've got multiple channels of the same account so that could be across different account types it could be your
credit card accounts it could be your current account it could be a mortgage it could be something else you hold with
the bank as well and so they might be trying to commit fraud by manipulating these different channels and then kind
of the final saw a deeper layer is where you've got multiple bad actors across multiple different channels as well and
at this point it becomes really difficult to actually identify what might be fraud and what isn't fraud and
you know in a more traditional sense of the word the way you would try and pick
up on this behavior is based on historical observations and then try to create a bunch of rules which would be
able to classify those and so you'd have a load the rules maybe like this where you'd be starting from things like is my
card over the limit have you got a certain high spike in transaction rate is such a card a known stolen card is a
terminal compromised and all these have to fit together to ultimately produce a
decision which says do we approve this transaction or not now there's some shortcomings with that
approach you're using static rulesets and these static rules become quite
out-of-date quite quickly so you're always behind and these static rules
they might actually be error-prone as well so the rules that maybe some of your fraud Department of setup might not
have been translated in the right way by their developers into the production environment and it becomes very
complicated and you've also got to think as well about the issues with scalability so it might work great say
90% of the time comes cyber monday Black Friday and so on what happens when you
suddenly get five times the amount of people coming to your website and trying to process transaction if your website
falls over and people can't make their purchases they'll go somewhere else so we really have a set of requirements for
a modern solution here and what we really need is something which is a comprises a set of dynamic rules really
they've got to be acting in real time and they've got to be self learning or cell phone reception so you need some
way of being able to maintain them easily and then finally they need to be
scalable so you need to be able to scale to save thousands or tens of thousands
of transactions per second without actually coming to put in any more extra effort to do that and so this is where
something like machine learning can come in and what I'm talking about today is a branch of machine learning it's actually
a relatively simple branch of machine learning there's very many different areas that you could look at the one I'm
going to look at today is a form of a classification and it's called
supervised learning as well so this works by understanding the data set and through the processor they're
algorithmically training a model it can start to understand hidden patterns and
the intention is you build a model based on those patterns which you can then put
date it through to make predictions and over time you want that model to be continuously evolving and building and
producing a more accurate model which can make better predictions with a fewer sort of incorrect fraud flags as time
goes on and so where does AWS fit into all of this well you might have heard
those AWS is having a major focus on machine learning and our belief is
really to put machine learning into the hands of every developer and data scientist and this really is a focus

at Amazon again verda mentioned this already but there's been a long history of using machine learning

workloads so that kind of brings me to the platform services part and this is
really where the focus of my talk is today so we often see that machine
learning is still considered a little bit too complicated for everyday developers
and you've got to go through a quite a wide number of different processes so you've got to do things like collect and
prepare your training data and then you've got to choose the kind of algorithm you're going to use to
actually start running your training jobs you then might have to set up and
manage your environment so if you're doing a distributed training environment you've got to spit up a bunch of
instances to actually do that and make sure they're communicating and then do things like training and tuning the
model and this can be sometimes an art some people at this point referred to it is not machine learning but magic
learning because it's almost taking em a bit of a trial and error approach to come up with the best parameters to
actually train your model and then once you're happy with that you've got to deploy it in production and you've got
to make sure that it can scale and be managed so that when you're running this at a sort of large scale you've got a
large number of transactions per second happening your model can cope with that and you're not spending all your time
having to add more compute capacity or more ability to deal with the amount of
requests that are coming through in more resiliency and so this is where sage maker comes in and sage maker is really
a managed service which is focused on providing the quickest and easiest way
for both data scientists and developers to get started with machine learning and taking something from an idea through to
a production deployment and it builds on this kind of pipeline that I mentioned
before so taking the first couple of elements you've got pre-built notebooks
to solve common problems and I'll show you a little bit of this in the demo later you've also got built in high
performance algorithms and these algorithms cover a number of different use cases so it's basic level you've got
things like linear regression you've got XT boost you can go deeper into things
like convolutional neural networks you can do RN ends as well you can do natural language processing and
understanding you can do machine translation and there's quite a number of different use cases out of the box
that you can take the built-in algorithms to do you can also take advantage of some of
the built-in frameworks as well so we've got the latest sort of stable versions
of Apache MX net intense flow in there and also things like cafe CNT K and PI
torch available so if you want to build your custom models this is where a lot of the customers today are focusing on
if you're relatively new to the world of machine learning you might look at some
of the built-in algorithms and the example notebooks and you can adapt these to just bring your own data and
then start making predictions against that the kind of next element is a
training element and so we say there's one-click training and what we mean by
that is you can set a model training and all you need to define is how many
instances you want to run it across what kind of instance you want to run it across as well so you could have a
cluster of CPUs or GPUs running without having to do all the back background
work to set up that infrastructure but you can also have a couple of parameters such as well in terms of how you might

element is the deployment so again this concept of having a one-click deployment and once you've got that model trained
and you've done the work of running it and storing it in it so a highly durable
place like s3 you want to deploy it you can deploy it simply by selecting the
model and again saying how much power you want to give that model in terms of compute capacity but you can also
cassette it to be auto scaling so if the number of requests per second comes in and it starts increasing
maybe the CPU or GPU load gpus load starts increasing you can up that water scale and you can have that
scale up and scale back and you can also do things like a/b testing as well so
you can have more than one type of model being hosted on the endpoint and you can wait the traffic accordingly so you

of test models that you want to see how well they perform and you could send 5%

training is you're not continuously running instances all the time like you might be if you were running your own

instances you want to run it on and how long you want to run and what type of instance you want to run that training
job on and then it will run that training job for you and once it's finished it will just kill the cluster
so you're only paying by the second for the actual training that takes place once that's training is completed you
stop paying for it and this can be really really cost effective when you're dealing with a large number of
developers and data scientists who sometimes are not quite as a disciplined when it comes to switching things off
